conclusion: The problem involves a charged ball in a uniform electric field.
The ball is in equilibrium under the influence of gravitational force, electric force, and tension.
A small ball with charge q is suspended by an insulating string with a length L.
The angle between the string and the vertical direction is θ.
The ball is exactly at rest.
The forces acting on the ball include gravitational force, electric force, and tension.
The ball is in equilibrium, so the net force in both directions is zero.
The vertical component of the tension balances the gravitational force.
The horizontal component of the tension balances the electric force.
The tension can be expressed as T = mg / cos(θ).
Substituting T into the horizontal equilibrium equation gives mg tan(θ) = qE.
Solving for E gives E = mg tan(θ) / q.
The electric field strength E is found to be E = mg tan(θ) / q.
